results.title: Wheat in Australia
results.brief_description: Primary teaching film surveying the wheat industry in Australia. Shows size and location of wheat areas, the beginnings of Governor Phillip’s 8-acre plot in 1788, the work of William Farrar in breeding new strains suited to Australian conditions from 1889 onwards, and the cycle of work which continues year after year on a modern mechanised farm. Discusses climate and soil requirements of wheat and explains why Australia’s wheat belt is situated between the 10-20 inches rainfall areas.

results.title: Wheat in Australia
results.brief_description: An instructional film that surveys the wheat industry in Australia: how wheat is grown, and how it is distributed within overseas and domestic markets; geographical areas of wheat growing; varieties; rust and the work of the Farrer; rotationand fertilization; ploughing, harrowing and sowing; hravesting and how a header works; bulk handling, testing and determination of FAQ; and the delivery to ships in ports or to flour mills. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Wheat country
results.creator_credit: Tim Wilson, ONF | NFB and Roger Blais
results.brief_description: Here is a film showing how each spring, prairie farmers renew their gamble with wind, frost, drought, rust and hail to begin again the cycle that may bring a good, or a lean, year. This story of big-scale wheat farming is told by a farm woman whose sons represent the fourth generation to operate a Saskatchewan farm.

results.title: Wheat
results.creator_credit: Douglas Jackson, ONF | NFB and Robert Nichol
results.brief_description: In this epic of the autumn harvest on the Canadian prairies, there is artistry in what the film shows of the seas of golden grain and the bold geometry carved on them by the invading fleet of combine harvesters. Canadian Northern is still the wheat of top quality. This film shows some of the men who grow it, as well as those who keep it moving to world markets.

results.title: Whazzat?
results.creator_credit: Todd Delerman, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Art Pierson
results.brief_description: Presents an adaptation of the East Indian folktale about six blind men who come upon an elephant and attempt to describe it. When each meets and touches the elephant he thinks he has encountered something different. Stresses the moral that cooperating with others can achieve more than working alone. For primary grades.

results.title: Whatever happened to La Pérouse?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Peter Kiernan and ACMI
results.brief_description: In addition to being a cherished family home, La Pérouse in Heidelberg, Victoria, is a historic building with a rich history, full of opera singers, vaudeville stars, and driving lessons.

results.title: Whatever Happened to Childhood?
results.brief_description: Childhood as today’s adults knew it no longer exists. Early exposure to the pressures of drug usage and changing sexual morality, along with a new indifference to, and participation in, criminal behaviour is forcing our children into becoming adults at a younger age. Both young people and adults tell their stories and explore our changing society.

results.title: Whatever happened to Baby Jane?
results.creator_credit: Seven Arts Productions and Robert Aldrich
results.brief_description: Bette Davis plays Jane Hudson, an aging alcoholic whose vauderville career as child-star “Baby Jane” has faded to obscurity. Her sister Blanche (Jane Crawford) lived in Jane’s shadow as a girl but enjoyed a successful adult career as a glamourous film star until an “accident” left her wheelchair-bound. The aging sisters live alone in a gloomy Hollywood mansion, with Jane becoming increasingly eccentric and keeping Blanche a virtual prisoner. After a series of horrific incidents, the obsessive relationship between the two draws to a sinister conclusion. Based on the novel by Henry Farrell.

results.title: Whatever
results.creator_credit: Ellin Baumel, Michelle Yahn, Kevin Segalla and Susan Skoog
results.brief_description: ‘Whatever’ is a coming-of-age film set in the mundane suburbia of New Jersey in the early 1980s. Anna (Liza Weill) hopes she will never be ordinary. Her dream is to escape to an art school in New York. Brenda, (Chad Morgan) her best friend, is both an exciting companion and a destructive force. Together they explore sex, drugs and rock’n roll, their experiences often proving less than positive. Anna comes to realise that the road to adulthood can involve some hard decisions, and that friendships can’t always last forever. With a soundtrack that includes Blondie, The Ramones, Motorhead and The Patti Smith Group, ‘Whatever’ portrays a gritty slice of suburban teenage life.
